intro: Quercus dentosa, commonly known as the Japanese oak, is a deciduous tree native to Japan and parts of Korea. It is characterized by its acorn-producing capsules and deeply lobed, serrated leaves that turn vibrant shades of red and yellow in autumn. The tree typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters and has a broad, spreading crown. Its bark is thick and scaly, providing a rugged appearance. Quercus dentosa is valued for its ornamental beauty and plays a role in local ecosystems by supporting various wildlife species.
